instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spins, No POST
threads.message: Hello. Got this board here. Board is completely clean, no corrosion at all. Fan spins, I get 1v05 and 1.8V at CPU VCORE, no chime, no POST. Fan spins at max after some time, CPU gets warm. Tried reballing SMC, no luck, tried new BIOS, no luck, verified all SPI resistors and all read ok. No visible broken traces, as I told, board is really clean, no corrosion in any regions. Tried also heating PCH/CPU with Amtech flux with hot air station at 320 degrees for 20 to 30 seconds to make the flux flow under the chip and board is the same. Diode mode on L7630 is 0.126 and I have steady 1.05V on it. Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spins, No POST
threads.message:
Check all voltages from page 11.
Be sure the resistors from LPC bus are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spins, No POST
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R1540</RESISTOR> - 33 ohms
<RESISTOR>R1541</RESISTOR> - 33,4 ohms
<RESISTOR>R1542</RESISTOR> - 33,2 ohms
<RESISTOR>R1543</RESISTOR> - 33 ohms
<RESISTOR>R1544</RESISTOR> - 33 ohms

L1270/75/90/95 - 1.05V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spins, No POST
threads.message:
Did you check the voltage on the output pin of the coils?
Do the same with <RESISTOR>R1280</RESISTOR>.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spins, No POST
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.325V
<RESISTOR>R1280</RESISTOR> - 1.05V on both pins. Yes, measuring on pin 2 of the mentioned coils

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spins, No POST
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spins, No POST
threads.message: Was what I thought... Any way to confirm it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan Spins, No POST
threads.message:
Unfortunatelly, this is not an exact science.
We don't have the test equipment which has the manufacturer in the production line.

Once we've checked the usual suspects, not much can do on it.
A simple corroded/broken resistor can cause the same symptom; can be a nightmare to solve such a failure.
Is no way to know what kind of failure can cause any resistor from the board...
